media:content.media:description: Silvio Horta, the creator of ABC's hit series Ugly Betty, was found dead Jan. 7, Variety reports. He was 45. Horta served as showrunner and head writer of Ugly Betty, whichstarred America Ferrera and Vanessa Williams and ran for four seasons on ABC from 2006 to 2010. The series, an American adaptation of a Colombian telenovela, won two Golden Globes. Horta was a Miami native who attended NYU's Tisch School of the Arts before moving to Los Angeles in 1996. He got his big break when he wrote the screenplay for the 1998 film Urban Legend, starring Jared Leto. He also wrote for sci-fi shows The Chronicle and Jake 2.0 before Ugly Betty became an ABC hit.

item.description: In celebration of their lives and contributions, we're honoring those we lost in 2020
item.dc:creator: TV Guide Editors

item.title: All the Movie Release Dates Delayed or Rescheduled Due to the Coronavirus

media:content.media:title: Hollywood's Major Movie Delays
media:content.media:description: Thanks to nationwide movie theater shutdowns amid the coronavirus pandemic, Hollywood's film release schedule is rapidly changing. Several major movies have skipped theaters altogether and instead hit on-demand and streaming services, but dozens of other high-profile pictures have simply delayed their release plans for a later date. To keep track of all of the studios' major delays, we've assembled this look at all of the movies that have had their release dates pushed back, including sequels like F9: Fast and Furious 9, Mission: Impossible 7, The Matrix 4, and Wonder Woman 1984; the latest James Bond movie No Time to Die; reboots of the CandyMan and Saw franchises; and Disney pictures like the live-action Mulan movie and the new Star Wars trilogy movies. Click through to see all of the major release date shakeups in Hollywood.

media:content.media:title: A Quiet Place II
media:content.media:description: The release of A Quiet Place II, the sequel to the hit 2018 horror film, was one of the first movies to be delayed as a result of the coronavirus outbreak, which director John Krasinski confirmed in an Instagram note to fans. Paramount has now rescheduled the movie's release for April 23, 2021. The film was originally scheduled for release in the U.K. and Australia on March 19 and in North America on March 20.

media:content.media:title: Antlers
media:content.media:description: The release of Guillermo Del Toro's Antlers has been delayed until Feb. 19, 2021.

media:content.media:title: The Avatar Sequels
media:content.media:description: Production on James Cameron's upcoming sequels to Avatar was delayed as a result of the coronavirus. Though the films returned to production earlier than most, their release dates were still delayed by about a year each. Avatar 2 will now arrive on Dec. 6, 2022; Avatar 3 has moved to Dec. 20, 2024; Avatar 4 has moved to Dec. 18, 2026; and Avatar 5 has been pushed back to Dec. 22, 2028.

media:content.media:title: Barb and Star Go to Vista Del Mar
media:content.media:description: The release date for Kristen Wiig-starring film Barb and Star Go to Vista Del Mar has moved to July 16, 2021.

media:content.media:title: The Batman
media:content.media:description: The Batman, starring Robert Pattinson as the titular superhero, has been pushed back to March. 4, 2022. Fellow DC superhero film Introducing The Flash is now set to premiere June 2, 2022, and Shazam 2 will launch on Nov. 4, 2022.

media:content.media:title: Black Widow
media:content.media:description: After a number of delays, the premiere of Marvel's Black Widow, starring Scarlett Johansson, has been moved to May 7, 2021. This has pushed back the entire Marvel slate: Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings moved to July 9, 2021, and Eternals moved to Nov. 5, 2021. The untitled third Spider-Man movie starring Tom Holland has been pushed back to Dec. 17, 2021. Thor: Love and Thunder has shifted to Feb. 11, 2022, and Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness is now set for March 25, 2022. Captain Marvel 2 is now set for July 8, 2022. The status of Black Panther 2 is currently unknown.

media:content.media:title: Candyman
media:content.media:description: The release date for Nia DaCosta's upcoming reboot of Candyman, executive produced by Jordan Peele (who also co-wrote the movie with DaCosta and Win Rosenfeld), has once again been moved, this time to an undetermined date in 2021.

media:content.media:title: Death on the Nile
media:content.media:description: Kenneth Branagh's new star-studded Agatha Christie adaptation Death on the Nile, which sees him return to his Murder on the Orient Express role as detective Hercule Poirot, has been pushed back to Dec. 18, 2020.

media:content.media:title: F9: Fast and Furious 9
media:content.media:description: The premiere of F9 has been pushed back almost a year. The North American premiere will now be April 2, 2021, with international debuts rolling out throughout that month.

media:content.media:title: The French Dispatch
media:content.media:description: Wes Anderson's The French Dispatch, a dramedy about an American magazine operating in a fictional French town, has now been delayed indefinitely. The movie was originally scheduled to hit theaters on Oct. 16, 2020.

media:content.media:title: Ghostbusters: Afterlife
media:content.media:description: Ghostbusters: Afterlife has been pushed to March 5, 2021. A direct sequel to the first two Ghostbusters movies, the film stars Carrie Coon, Finn Wolfhard, Mckenna Grace, and Paul Rudd. Bill Murray, Dan Aykroyd, Ernie Hudson, Sigourney Weaver, and Annie Potts all reprise their roles from the original films.

media:content.media:title: The Hitman's Wife's Bodyguard
media:content.media:description: The sequel to The Hitman's Bodyguard, starring Ryan Reynolds and Samuel L. Jackson, has moved to Aug. 20, 2021.

media:content.media:title: John Wick: Chapter 4
media:content.media:description: The next installment of the Keanu Reeves-led film series has officially been pushed back to May 27, 2022, a year after its originally scheduled release date.

media:content.media:title: Jackass 4
media:content.media:description: The next movie in the Jackass franchise has now been pushed back to Sept. 3, 2021.

media:content.media:title: Jungle Cruise
media:content.media:description: Disney's Jungle Cruise, starring Dwayne Johnson and Emily Blunt, has been moved to July 30, 2021.

media:content.media:title: The King's Man
media:content.media:description: The release of the Kingsmen prequel The King's Man has been pushed to Feb. 12, 2021. The movie, a World War I period piece directed by Matthew Vaughn, stars Ralph Fiennes, Daniel Bruhl, Gemma Arterton, Stanley Tucci, Matthew Goode, Aaron Taylor-Johnson, and Djimon Hounsou.

media:content.media:title: The Last Duel
media:content.media:description: Ridley Scott's The Last Duel has been delayed until Oct. 15, 2021. The movie stars Matt Damon, Ben Affleck, Adam Driver, and Jodie Comer.

media:content.media:title: Last Night in Soho
media:content.media:description: Edgar Wright's Last Night in Soho has now had its release date pushed back to April 23, 2021. The psychological thriller, which stars Anya Taylor-Joy and Matt Smith, centers on a girl who finds herself suddenly transported to the 1960s, where she meets her hero, an aspiring singer.

media:content.media:title: The Matrix 4
media:content.media:description: Due to production shutdowns, the Wachowskis' highly anticipated next installment in the Matrix franchise was pushed back to April 1, 2022. Warner Bros. gave its original May 2021 release date to Godzilla vs. Kong. The anticipated sequel will see Keanu Reeves reprise his role as Neo, alongside Carrie-Anne Moss as Trinity and Jada Pinkett Smith as Niobe.

media:content.media:title: Minions: The Rise of Gru
media:content.media:description: Minions: The Rise of Gru was pushed back a full year, to July 2, 2021.

media:content.media:title: Mission: Impossible Sequels
media:content.media:description: The seventh installment of the Mission Impossible franchise has now been pushed to Nov. 19, 2021, and Mission: Impossible 8 will move its release date to Nov. 4, 2022.

media:content.media:title: Mulan
media:content.media:description: Disney's live-action adaptation of Mulan made its debut on Sept. 4, 2020, on Disney+. The film is under "premiere access" on the platform and costs $29.99 to stream, but it will go wide to all Disney+ users on Dec. 4, 2020. The film was also released theatrically in countries where theaters have reopened.

media:content.media:title: The New Mutants
media:content.media:description: The New Mutants was theatrically released in the United States on Aug. 20, 2020, after a number of delays from its original premiere date in April 2018.

media:content.media:title: No Time to Die
media:content.media:description: For those who are hoping to see Daniel Craig back in action as Agent 007, you're in for a long wait. No Time to Die is now set to hit theaters on April 2, 2021, a year after its initial planned release date. The movie was the first major film to push back its release date in the spring, though Craig still showed up to host Saturday Night Live as scheduled in March. He even offered fans a fake clip from the film.

media:content.media:title: The Personal History of David Copperfield
media:content.media:description: The Personal History of David Copperfield, starring Dev Patel, was theatrically released Aug. 28, 2020 after a slight delay.

media:content.media:title: Raya and the Last Dragon
media:content.media:description: Disney's Raya and the Last Dragon, starring Kelly Marie Tran, will now debut March 12, 2021.

media:content.media:title: Sing 2
media:content.media:description: Universal pushed the release date for its sequel to the animated film Sing to Dec. 22, 2021.

media:content.media:title: Soul
media:content.media:description: Pixar film Soul will now debut in theaters on Nov. 20, 2020, after originally being scheduled for a June 19 premiere.

media:content.media:title: Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse Sequel
media:content.media:description: Sony Pictures Classics has pushed back the sequel to Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse, which will be released on Oct. 7, 2022, instead of April 8, 2022. Sony also bumped the Spider-Man spinoff Morbius to March 19, 2021.

media:content.media:title: Spiral: From the Book of Saw
media:content.media:description: Chris Rock and Samuel L. Jackson's Saw reboot Spiral took over John Wick: Chapter 4's original release date and will now debut on May 21, 2021.

media:content.media:title: Untitled Star Wars Movies
media:content.media:description: LucasFilm/Disney has delayed its upcoming trilogy of new Star Wars movies -- originally scheduled for Dec. 16, 2022, Dec. 20, 2024, and Dec. 18, 2026 -- each by a full year.

media:content.media:title: Tenet
media:content.media:description: Even amid widespread lockdowns, Christopher Nolan was set on a full theatrical debut for his newest mind-bending drama, Tenet. The movie's original July release date was pushed back three times, but Warner Bros. finally released the film in the U.S. on Sept. 3.

media:content.media:title: The Tiger's Apprentice
media:content.media:description: Paramount's animated adaptation of The Tiger's Apprentice fantasy novels has been pushed back a year to Feb. 19, 2023.

media:content.media:title: Top Gun: Maverick
media:content.media:description: Top Gun: Maverick, Paramount's highly anticipated sequel to Tom Cruise's iconic '80s hit, has been delayed. The movie is now scheduled to debut on July 2, 2021.

media:content.media:title: Uncharted
media:content.media:description: Uncharted, starring Tom Holland, has been moved to July 16, 2021.

media:content.media:title: West Side Story
media:content.media:description: Steven Spielberg's West Side Story, starring Ansel Elgort and Rachel Zegler, has been pushed back a year. The anticipated musical is now set to debut on Dec. 10, 2021.

media:content.media:title: Wonder Woman 1984
media:content.media:description: Warner Bros. has pushed back the release of Wonder Woman 1984 to Dec. 25, 2020. The latest move comes after a number of earlier changes to the film's release date.

item.description: Hollywood's release date schedule looks a whole lot different right now
item.dc:creator: Amanda Bell

item.title: Gilmore Girls Cast Then and Now

media:content.media:title: Gilmore Girls Cast: Then and Now
media:content.media:description: Gilmore Girls, the beloved WB show set in the quaint (and fictional) Connecticut town of Stars Hollow, is turning 20 years old, which means it's older than Lorelai was when she had Rory!The series introduced audiences to as about as many future stars as it did quirky characters: The Handmaid Tale's Alexis Bledel, Supernatural's Jared Padalecki, This Is Us' Milo Ventimiglia, The Resident's Matt Czuchry, and two-time Oscar nominee Melissa McCarthy are among those who got their big breaks on the coffee-fueled, mother-daughter-focused comedy-drama created by Amy Sherman-Palladino. As we celebrate the show's anniversary, let's revisit the stellar cast, many of whom reunited for the 2016 Netflix miniseries Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life, and see what they're up to today!

media:content.media:title: Alexis Bledel Then
media:content.media:description: Alexis Bledel was an undergrad at New York University when she won the role of Rory Gilmore, the younger but more mature half of Gilmore Girls' main mother-daughter duo. Bledel, a former model, played the Chilton-and-Yale-educated aspiring journalist, and remained with the show for all seven seasons -- even if the writers did have Rory steal a yacht that one time. Bledel reprised the role in the Netflix miniseries Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life.

media:content.media:title: Alexis Bledel Now
media:content.media:description: Outside of Gilmore Girls, Alexis Bledel has starred in the Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants movies, and had a recurring role on Mad Men. As of 2020, she stars as Emily on Hulu's The Handmaid's Tale (pictured); she won a Primetime Emmy for her work on the dystopian drama.

media:content.media:title: Lauren Graham Then
media:content.media:description: Lauren Graham starred in a series of short-lived sitcoms (Townies, Conrad Bloom, M.Y.O.B.) before she found the job that stuck: playing Gilmore Girls' Lorelai Gilmore, Stars Hollow's fast-talking, coffee-swigging, pop-culture-referencing innkeeper and devoted single mom. Like Bledel and much of the cast, Graham returned to the franchise for Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life.

media:content.media:title: Lauren Graham Now
media:content.media:description: After Gilmore Girls, Lauren Graham played another single mom, Sarah Braverman, for six uber-dramatic seasons on Parenthood. As of 2020, she was rocking out on NBC's musical dramedy Zoey's Extraordinary Playlist (pictured).

media:content.media:title: Keiko Agena Then
media:content.media:description: Keiko Agena played Rory Gilmore's BFF, Lane Kim, who had her own band, not to mention her own mother issues. She returned to the Stars Hollow universe for Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life.

media:content.media:title: Keiko Agena Now
media:content.media:description: On the Fox crime drama Prodigal Son, Keiko Agena rocks gloves, not a drum set, as medical examiner Dr. Edrisa Tanaka.

media:content.media:title: Melissa McCarthy Then
media:content.media:description: Melissa McCarthy had appeared in an episode of her cousin Jenny McCarthy's 1997-1998 sitcom Jenny, and had a handful of other screen credits when she was cast as Lorelai Gilmore's indispensable Independence Inn coworker -- and BFF -- Sookie St. James. She reprised the always-cooking role in Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life.

media:content.media:title: Melissa McCarthy Now
media:content.media:description: Melissa McCarthy has basically been everywhere since Gilmore Girls. She co-starred in the 2007-2009 TV comedy Samantha Who?, enjoyed Primetime Emmy-winning sitcom success in 2010-2016's Mike & Molly, and became a box office force via the 2011 blockbuster Bridesmaids, for which she earned her first career Oscar nomination. In 2020, she hosted Season 4 of Little Big Shots (pictured), the NBC variety series she also helps executive produce.

media:content.media:title: Scott Patterson Then
media:content.media:description: On Gilmore Girls, Scott Patterson poured a mean cup of joe as Luke Danes, the no-nonsense proprietor of Luke's Diner. Lorelai herself might say Luke was curmudgeonly, and she liked him: Luke and Lorelai are on our ranked list of the 50 greatest CW couples.

media:content.media:title: Scott Patterson Now
media:content.media:description: Post-Gilmore Girls, Scott Patterson starred in the short-lived NBC sci-fi show The Event. He re-donned Luke's baseball cap and flannel shirt for Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life (pictured).

media:content.media:title: Liza Weil Then
media:content.media:description: Liza Weil played Rory Gilmore's Chilton rival turned Bangles buddy and Yale classmate Paris Geller. Weil was among the GG stars who returned for the Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life.

media:content.media:title: Liza Weil Now
media:content.media:description: From 2014-2020, Liza Weil played attorney Bonnie Winterbottom on the ABC crime-drama How to Get Away with Murder.

media:content.media:title: Jared Padalecki Then
media:content.media:description: Jared Padelecki began his Gilmore Girls journey in the pilot, when he was introduced as the Rosemary's Baby-aware Chicago transplant Dean Forester. Over the years, his character became Rory Gilmore's first kiss, first boyfriend, and first, well, you know.

media:content.media:title: Jared Padalecki Now
media:content.media:description: Jared Padalecki left Gilmore Girls after Season 5 (and after Dean was shown to be not-so dreamy). He promptly began a 15-season run on the CW's Supernatural (pictured). Despite his demon-hunting duties for that show, Padadelecki reprised his Gilmore Girls role for the "Fall" episode of Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life.

media:content.media:title: Kelly Bishop Then
media:content.media:description: Kelly Bishop was a Tony Award-winning legend (A Chorus Line) best known as the mother of Jennifer Grey's Baby in Dirty Dancing when she was cast as another on-screen mom: Emily Gilmore, the Lorelai-vexing maternal unit who agrees to pay for Rory's Chilton tuition in exchange for more opportunities to vex Lorelai.

media:content.media:title: Kelly Bishop Now
media:content.media:description: Kelly Bishop, who had a role on Gilmore Girls creator Amy Sherman-Palladino's Bunheads, returned to the world of Stars Hollow for Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life (pictured).

media:content.media:title: Yanic Truesdale Then
media:content.media:description: Viewers are introduced to Yanic Truesdale in the Gilmore Girls pilot; the French Canadian actor plays Michel Gerard, originally the Independence Inn's front-desk clerk -- the exacting front-desk clerk.

media:content.media:title: Yanic Truesdale Now
media:content.media:description: Yanic Truesdale returned to play the ever-dapper Michel Gerard in Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life (pictured). In 2020, Truesdale was seen in the French-language Canadian drama, Les Mecs (translation: The Guys).

media:content.media:title: Liz Torres Then
media:content.media:description: Veteran actress Liz Torres, a two-time Primetime Emmy nominee for the 1990s sitcom The John Larroquette Show, played Stars Hollow's chain-smoking dance instructor, Miss Patty, for the duration of the show. She reprised the role for Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life.

media:content.media:title: Liz Torres Now
media:content.media:description: Liz Torres is seen at an event in Los Angeles in 2019. Her recent credits include guest appearances on One Day at a Time and Devious Maids.

media:content.media:title: Milo Ventimiglia Then
media:content.media:description: A baby-faced Milo Ventimiglia joined the Gilmore Girls cast in Season 2. He played Jess Mariano, the New York-born nephew of Luke, and the Stars Hollow bad boy who actually ended up being a pretty good match for Rory.

media:content.media:title: Milo Ventimiglia Now
media:content.media:description: Since 2016, Milo Ventimiglia, who appeared in four Gilmore Girls seasons, and who reprised Jess for Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life, has starred as solid-citizen, non-bad-boy Jack Pearson on NBC's This Is Us.

media:content.media:title: Matt Czuchry Then
media:content.media:description: Matt Czuchry joined the Gilmore Girls cast in Season 5 as preppy publishing scion and Yale student Logan Huntzberger, the supposedly charming cad whom Rory jumps off a scaffolding with, and ultimately rejects a proposal from. (Logan is also involved with the yacht-stealing scandal.) Czuchry returned to the role for Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life, presumably so that Logan could again help Rory show off her unflattering side: In the miniseries, it's revealed Rory and the engaged-to-another Logan are having an affair.

media:content.media:title: Matt Czuchry Now
media:content.media:description: Post-Gilmore Girls, Matt Czuchry scored a recurring role on Friday Night Lights, and then a starring role as Cary Agos on The Good Wife. Since 2018, he's played the title character, Dr. Conrad Hawkins, on Fox's The Resident (pictured).

media:content.media:title: Vanessa Marano Then
media:content.media:description: Vanessa Marano was 13 when she made her Gilmore Girls debut as April Nardini, the daughter Luke never knew he had, in Season 6's "The Prodigal Daughter Returns."

media:content.media:title: Vanessa Marano Now
media:content.media:description: Vanessa Marano moved on from Gilmore Girls to star in the ABC Family/Freeform series Switched at Birth. Since 2018, Marano has starred as Nancy Graves, one of the deceased characters in the Snap Original series, The Dead Girls Detective Agency (pictured).

media:content.media:title: Chad Michael Murray Then
media:content.media:description: Chad Michael Murray made his first prime-time impression with the Gilmore Girls as Tristan DuGray, Rory's bullying, "Mary"-taunting Chilton classmate whom Rory ends up kissing anyway because, well, she's a Gilmore, we guess. Murray appeared in Seasons 1 and 2 en route to a stint on Dawson's Creek and a starring role on One Tree Hill.

media:content.media:title: Chad Michael Murray Now
media:content.media:description: Chad Michael Murray is the rare Gilmore Girls alum who did not return for Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life. (He said he "wasn't available at the time"; the role was instead played by Anton Narinskiy.) In 2019, Murray played Edgar Evernever on the CW's Riverdale (pictured).

media:content.media:title: Emily Kuroda Then
media:content.media:description: For the duration of Gilmore Girls, and then again for Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life, Emily Kuroda played Mrs. Kim, Lane's mother and minder who's so strict that her daughter originally hides her rock-'n'-roll ambitions from her. (Insert sad face.)

media:content.media:title: Emily Kuroda Now
media:content.media:description: Emily Kuroda is seen as a patient in a 2018 episode of Fox's The Resident, starring fellow Gilmore Girls alum Matt Czuchry. In 2020, Kuroda reunited with her TV daughter, Keiko Agena, to host an UPtv GG Mother's Day marathon.

media:content.media:title: Edward Herrmann Then
media:content.media:description: The Primetime Emmy-winning Edward Herrmann was best known for playing President Franklin D. Roosevelt, or maybe for his villainous turn in The Lost Boys, before he became the Gilmore Girls' outnumbered Gilmore male, Richard Gilmore.

media:content.media:title: Edward Herrmann Now
media:content.media:description: Post-Gilmore Girls, Edward Herrmann remained a familiar prime-time figure. He had a recurring role as attorney Lionel Deerfield on The Good Wife; he is seen here in a 2013 episode that would prove to be his final appearance on the drama. Herrmann died Dec. 31, 2014. He was 71.In Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life, Hermann's Richard Gilmore is said to have suffered a fatal heart attack; the character's death is the jumping-off point for the Netflix miniseries.

media:content.media:title: Sally Struthers Then
media:content.media:description: Sally Struthers, a two-time Primetime Emmy-winner for the TV classic All in the Family, lent her comic talent to Gilmore Girls as the daffy, cat-loving Babette Dell.

media:content.media:title: Sally Struthers Now
media:content.media:description: In Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life (pictured), Sally Struthers reunited with her Gilmore Girls husband, Ted Rooney, who played the cool, piano-playing Morey Dell.

media:content.media:title: Danny Strong Then
media:content.media:description: Danny Strong had credits in Saved by the Bell: The New Class and, most prominently, Buffy the Vampire Slayer, when he joined the Gilmore Girls cast in Season 4 as Doyle McMaster, Rory and Paris' editor at the Yale Daily News (who eventually becomes Paris' boyfriend and husband).

media:content.media:title: Danny Strong Now
media:content.media:description: Danny Strong would've made Doyle McMaster proud by branching out into writing (and producing) after Gilmore Girls. He won two Primetime Emmys for his work on the HBO movie Game Change. He wrote the hit movie The Butler, and teamed with that film's director, Lee Daniels, to create the hit Fox drama Empire. All the while, Strong has continued to act, appearing in Empire, Showtime's Billions (pictured) -- and two episodes of Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life.

media:content.media:title: David Sutcliffe Then
media:content.media:description: David Sutcliffe played Gilmore Girls' original bad boyfriend, Christopher Hayden, Lorelai's former high school flame, Rory's (mostly) absentee father, and Lorelai's eventual (short-lived) husband. Sutcliffe pops up for the first time in the Season 1 episode "That Damn Donna Reed"; he went on to appear in every season, save the fourth.

media:content.media:title: David Sutcliffe Now
media:content.media:description: After Gilmore Girls, David Sutcliffe played the boyfriend of Addison Montgomery (Kate Walsh) on Private Practice. He returned to his Christopher Hayden roots for Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life (pictured).

media:content.media:title: Jackson Douglas Then
media:content.media:description: On Gilmore Girls, Jackson Douglas played Jackson Belleville, the farmer who starts out selling vegetables to chef Sookie St. James, and ends up marrying the character in the Season 2 finale, "I Can't Get Started."

media:content.media:title: Jackson Douglas Now
media:content.media:description: Jackson Douglas appears as Jackson in the "Spring" installment of Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life (pictured).

media:content.media:title: Sean Gunn Then
media:content.media:description: Sean Gunn played a couple of different characters in two early Gilmore Girls episodes before debuting in "Cinnamon's Wake" as Kirk Gleason, one of Stars Hollow's quirky denizens -- the one with the night terrors, to be precise. Gunn reprised the role in Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life.

media:content.media:title: Sean Gunn Now
media:content.media:description: Sean Gunn, the brother of Marvel Cinematic Universe director James Gunn, played Kraglin in his sibling's Guardians of the Galaxy and Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 (pictured), as well as in Avengers: Endgame. He's set to return to the MCU in the upcoming Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3.

media:content.media:title: Todd Lowe Then
media:content.media:description: Todd Lowe joined the Gilmore Girls family in Season 3 as Lane's bandmate (and future husband) Zach Van Gerbig. Over the years, Lane's band also featured musicians played by Adam Brody and Skid Row rocker Sebastian Bach.

media:content.media:title: Todd Lowe Now
media:content.media:description: Todd Lowe stuck around as Zach, and reunited with Keiko Agena in Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life. The TV couple welcomed twins in Gilmore Girls' Season 7, and were back living in Stars Hollow in Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life.

media:content.media:title: Michael Winters Then
media:content.media:description: On Gilmore Girls, Michael Winters played Stars Hollow's know-it-all town selectman, Taylor Doose.

media:content.media:title: Michael Winters Now
media:content.media:description: Michael Winters reprised his role as Taylor, and resumed his bossy Stars Hollow ways, in Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life (pictured).

item.description: Stars Hollows had a lot of stars.
item.category: Gilmore Girls: A Year In The Life
item.dc:creator: Joal Ryan

item.title: 19 Stars Who Were on Gilmore Girls Before They Were Famous

media:content.media:title: Max Greenfield, Abigail Spencer, and Adam Brody; Gilmore Girls
media:content.media:description: There are so many reasons to love Gilmore Girls, but easily one of the best parts of the show was its incredible cast. Even beyond Lauren Graham, Alexis Bledel, Kelly Bishop, Melissa McCarthy, Scott Patterson, Keiko Agena, and the rest of the Stars Hollow crew, the series had an impressive roster of supporting players and guest stars — many of whom would go on to become big stars in their own right in the 20 years since Gilmore Girls premiered. Click ahead to look back on 19 stars who appeared on Gilmore Girls before they were famous, including actors from Parks and Recreation, Timeless, The O.C., The Vampire Diaries, and Mad Men.

media:content.media:title: Jon Hamm
media:content.media:description: Before Hamm was the slick Don Draper on Mad Men, he was one of the worst dates Lorelai had ever been out with. Hamm appeared in a Season 3 episode as Peyton Sanders, the handsome son of one of Emily's friends, which meant that even though Lorelai hated every second of their date, she gets guilted into a second one to appease her mother. Unfortunately, Lorelai and Peyton's trip to see David Bowie all happened off-screen and he was never seen again.

media:content.media:title: Chad Michael Murray
media:content.media:description: On One Tree Hill, Murray might have played the kid from the wrong side of the tracks, but on Gilmore Girls, his character's family probably owned the tracks and the entire train line. For two seasons, Murray played Rory's Chilton classmate, Tristan, who expressed his feelings for Rory by constantly mocking her and insulting her boyfriend Dean.

media:content.media:title: Nick Offerman
media:content.media:description: Long before he was the gruff mentor of Leslie Knope on Parks and Recreation, Offerman was the gruff brother of Jackson on Gilmore Girls. The actor appeared in two episodes as Beau Belleville.

media:content.media:title: Jane Lynch
media:content.media:description: The same year Lynch starred in the mockumentary Best in Show, she also appeared as a nurse who gets harassed by Emily when Richard is hospitalized in Season 1.

media:content.media:title: Krysten Ritter
media:content.media:description: In between her roles on Veronica Mars and Breaking Bad, Ritter played Rory's friend, Lucy, on Gilmore Girls' final season.

media:content.media:title: Rami Malek
media:content.media:description: We rarely saw much of Lane's life at the Seventh-day Adventist college. Otherwise, we would have gotten many more scenes with the Mr. Robot star, whose first acting job was playing Lane's classmate with an odd obsession with assistant pastor Eric.

media:content.media:title: Adam Brody
media:content.media:description: We like to imagine that in an alternate universe Brody stayed on Gilmore Girls as Lane's lovable boyfriend Dave Rygalski. Unfortunately, in the real world Brody left the show for The O.C. after Gilmore Girls Season 3 and Dave left Stars Hollow for -- you guessed it -- California.

media:content.media:title: Victoria Justice
media:content.media:description: The former Nickelodeon star made her onscreen debut as a young attendee at a Lord of the Rings-themed birthday party that Lorelai and Sookie catered. Justice's character wasn't a fan of Sookie's elaborate spread, leading to a hilarious face-off between the duo that ended in tears for one and a major existential crisis for the other.

media:content.media:title: Max Greenfield
media:content.media:description: Years before Greenfield appeared on Veronica Mars, the New Girl actor played a drunken attendee at Dean's bachelor party who attempted to bond with Luke over sharing the same name.

media:content.media:title: Riki Lindhome
media:content.media:description: You know this hilariously talented comedienne as one half of Garfunkel & Oates. Before her comic duo days, she appeared in Seasons 3, 5, and 6 of Gilmore Girls as Juliet.

media:content.media:title: Nasim Pedrad
media:content.media:description: Pedrad only had a few credits to her name before she landed Saturday Night Live. One of those was the role of a waitress who served a very drunk and a very sad Rory in Season 6.

media:content.media:title: Ben Falcone
media:content.media:description: Melissa McCarthy's husband appeared on Season 3 of Gilmore Girls as Mr. Brink, the executor of Fran's will. Falcone has since starred in many films, including Bridesmaids, alongside McCarthy.

media:content.media:title: Brandon Routh
media:content.media:description: Not only did Gilmore Girls land The Bangles for the Season 1 episode "Concert Interruptus," but the show also landed the future Superman. The Superman Returns and Legends of Tomorrow actor played a hottie at a Bangles concert who convinced Madeline and Louise to ditch the show and come to a party with him, much to Lorelai's chagrin.

media:content.media:title: Danny Pudi
media:content.media:description: The Community star appeared in four episodes as Raj, a Yale Daily News writer during Rory's stint as editor.

media:content.media:title: Arielle Kebbel
media:content.media:description: The John Tucker Must Die and Vampire Diaries actor played Lindsay, Dean's wife, on Gilmore Girls.

media:content.media:title: Seth MacFarlane
media:content.media:description: The Family Guy creator played one of Lorelai's obnoxious business school classmates who judged Lorelai harshly for coming from money. He also voiced Emily's lawyer in a Season 3 episode, but was never seen onscreen in that role.

media:content.media:title: Masi Oka
media:content.media:description: The Heroes star had a minor role as a Harvard student who debates relativism with Rory when she sneaks into a class in Season 2.

media:content.media:title: Matt Jones
media:content.media:description: In his very first TV role, Jones played Morgan, who cheered on Jackson as he fried a turkey for Thanksgiving. He'd go on to bigger small screen roles on Breaking Bad and Mom.

media:content.media:title: Abigail Spencer
media:content.media:description: This Timeless and Suits star had a brief part during Gilmore Girls' sixth season.

item.description: See everyone who stopped by Stars Hollow on their way to the top
item.dc:creator: Sadie Gennis

item.title: Gilmore Girls Guys, Ranked

media:content.media:description: As Gilmore Girls celebrates its 20th anniversary (yes, really!), we're looking back on the WB-turned-CW dramedy and celebrating the men of Stars Hollow, from Luke Danes (Scott Patterson) and Jess Mariano (Milo Ventimiglia) to Tristan Dugray (Chad Michael Murray) and Michel Gerard (Yanic Truesdale). Who will come out on top?

media:content.media:title: 24. Jason Stiles (Chris Eigeman)
media:content.media:description: Being quirky is not a fault in the world of Gilmore Girls. In fact, it's preferred! But there is something about how Jason's particular eccentricities, combined with his smug, rich lifestyle, that rubbed us the wrong way. Plus, who sues their girlfriend's father? So not cool, Jason.

media:content.media:title: 23. Taylor Doose (Michael Winters)
media:content.media:description: Taylor is the man everyone in Stars Hollow loves to hate (just sometimes without that "love" part). He's domineering, rude, holier-than-thou, petty, bossy, selfish -- the list of his bad qualities is nearly endless. However, he is also the man who makes sure all of the Stars Hollow festivals go off without a hitch, so we guess Taylor isn't all bad.

media:content.media:title: 22. Christopher Hayden (David Sutcliffe)
media:content.media:description: Where do we even start with Christopher? The time he abandoned Lorelai to raise Rory on her own? Or the time he abandoned Lorelai to raise Gigi with Sherry? Or maybe the time he broke up Luke and Lorelai at Emily and Richard's vow renewal? How do you spell deadbeat? C-H-R-I-S.

media:content.media:title: 21. Brad Langford (Adam Wylie)
media:content.media:description: Poor Brad. He likely has PTSD from being terrorized by Paris at Chilton for all those years. At least after Brad discovered his love of musical theater he was able to face his fears and find the brave little Sondheim within.

media:content.media:title: 20. Colin McCrae (Alan Loayza)
media:content.media:description: There's no question that Colin is the weak link in Logan's Yale crew. He is the least charming of the bunch and has few other notable features besides his womanizing ways.

media:content.media:title: 19. Tristan Dugray (Chad Michael Murray)
media:content.media:description: Smarmy. That is the only word to describe Tristan. And yet, he holds a special place in our hearts. The way he taunted Mary Rory was despicable, but you've got to admit, the man had chutzpah! And let's be real: Is he really much worse than any of Rory's actual boyfriends?

media:content.media:title: 18. Marty (Wayne Wilcox)
media:content.media:description: Rory clearly has problems, because why she would date a trio of men who treated her badly and never give Marty a second look is seriously cuckoo bananas. Marty's smart, charming, emotionally present, pop culture savvy, and he supplied her with food -- he's everything a Gilmore girl needs in a guy! That is, until he lied to his girlfriend, Lucy, reminding us that nobody's perfect after all.

media:content.media:title: 17. T.J. (Michael DeLuise)
media:content.media:description: Luke might have been wary of T.J. at first, but Liz's husband quickly won everyone over with his charming buffoonery. T.J. is a simple guy, but he would have gone to the end of the world for Liz. And if he gets the Luke Danes stamp of approval, he's good enough for us too.

media:content.media:title: 16. Morey Dell (Ted Rooney)
media:content.media:description: A man of few words, Morey is as devoted a husband as they come. He does mostly whatever Babette asks and his too-cool-for-school attitude is the perfect counterbalance to her over-the-top energy.

media:content.media:title: 15. Dean Forester (Jared Padalecki)
media:content.media:description: Yes, he built her a car. We get it. It's romantic. But he also did the not-so romantic act of publicly humiliating Rory by dumping her in front of her friends and family -- twice! Not to mention the third time, when he broke up with her because she didn't say "I love you" fast enough. Then there's the whole cheating-on-his-wife thing and the time he married Lindsay even though he knew he was in love with Rory. But as long as our list of grievances is, we also know that, despite Dean's flaws, he had a good heart. Plus, he always treated Lorelai well.

media:content.media:title: 14. Finn (Tanc Slade)
media:content.media:description: Finn is the best part of Logan's posse. His ridiculous schemes and Australian accent made him a scene-stealer from the start. We totally would have joined the Life and Death Brigade if it meant hanging out with him.

media:content.media:title: 13. The Town Troubadour (Grant Lee Phillips)
media:content.media:description: There's very little we know about the Town Troubadour beyond his music, but what more do you need? He's the man who provides the soundtrack to Stars Hollow! That's a way more romantic job than building furniture. (Sorry, Aiden Shaw, but it's true.)

media:content.media:title: 12. Brian Fuller (John Cabrera)
media:content.media:description: Everyone forgets about poor Brian -- and we don't understand why! He's funny, sweet, and a total nerd. Sure, Brian might not be about that rock 'n' roll life that Lane wants to live, but we're still groupies for Hep Alien's asthmatic bass player.

media:content.media:title: 11. Michel Gerard (Yanic Truesdale)
media:content.media:description: Though he rarely shows affection towards anyone except his prized chow puppies, Chin-Chin and Paw-Paw, Michel loved Lorelai and Sookie as much as we do. At his core, Michel is a good -- albeit high-maintenance and rude -- friend who always knows how to make us laugh (often at his own expense).

media:content.media:title: 10. Kirk Gleason (Sean Gunn)
media:content.media:description: Kirk is simultaneously a man of many talents and a master of none. He's had every job in Stars Hollow, and yet seems to be good at nothing. But there is one thing at which Kirk always succeeds, and that's making us smile each and every time he manages to drive Taylor or Luke crazy.

media:content.media:title: 9. Max Medina (Scott Cohen)
media:content.media:description: Poor Max. He was one of the few men who Rory actually looked forward to having as a stepdad. That is, before Lorelai crushed his heart. In the end, Max's perfection may have been his downfall, because it's hard for someone so reliable to keep a person's attention in the over-the-top world of Stars Hollow.

media:content.media:title: 8. Doyle McMaster (Danny Strong)
media:content.media:description: Let's give credit where credit's due: Paris is a whole lot of person, and anyone who enters into a relationship with her deserves our respect. And not only does Doyle love Paris for all her intense idiosyncrasies, he has more than a few of his own. But like Paris, Doyle's quirks are exactly what make him so great.

media:content.media:title: 7. Zack Van Gerbig (Todd Lowe)
media:content.media:description: Lane was Stars Hollow's coolest resident, which means she needed a pretty cool dude. Fortunately, she found Zack, who not only shares her love of music, but is as weird as she is (remember his banjo playing and obsession with cleaning products?). It might have taken a while for Zack to process Lane having feelings for him, but afterwards, he was all-in and we're glad the pair found their happily-ever-after together.

media:content.media:title: 6. Logan Huntzberger (Matt Czuchry)
media:content.media:description: The most divisive of all of Rory's boyfriends, Logan was an entitled trust fund kid with a heart of gold. Over the course of the series, Logan helped Rory challenge herself in ways no boyfriend had done before. And in tandem, he also challenged himself to break away from his family's claustrophobic expectations and Logan matured into a thoughtful, caring, and intrepid young man. That is, until the revival completely trashed all of his character development, but we firmly stand by our decision to ignore this devolution.

media:content.media:title: 5. Jess Mariano (Milo Ventimiglia)
media:content.media:description: The account of all the bad things Jess did is longer than Rory's reading list. He tried to force himself on her, he attempted to make her run away with him and -- oh yeah -- he moved across the country without telling her. Yet Jess is so charming, smart, and irreverent that we can't help but love the Stars Hollow bad boy. And out of all of Rory's terrible boyfriends, Jess is the one who knew her best and ultimately fulfilled his potential to become a voice of reason in the revival, Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life.

media:content.media:title: 4. Dave Rygalski (Adam Brody)
media:content.media:description: As much as we love Seth Cohen, we can't help but wonder what would have been had Brody not left Gilmore Girls for The O.C. Dave Rygalski is not only a great name to say out loud, but a perfect human being. Dave even managed to get Mrs. Kim's stamp of approval, which is the highest accolade a love interest can get. And remember when he stayed up all night reading the entire Bible in order to take Lane to prom?

media:content.media:title: 3. Jackson Belleville (Jackson Douglas)
media:content.media:description: Jackson and Sookie can fight like cats and dogs -- but only when it comes to produce. Otherwise, he's the most supporting, loving, and responsible partner a person could ask for. And he's so willing to help out his friends, he'll even sleep with the zucchinis (literally).

media:content.media:title: 2. Richard Gilmore (Edward Herrmann)
media:content.media:description: Lorelai's parents were far from perfect, but that doesn't stop us from loving Richard Gilmore. Sure, he had his bad moments, but even Richard's worst actions were motivated by simply wanting the best for his family.

media:content.media:title: 1. Luke Danes (Scott Patterson)
media:content.media:description: Despite being someone who's very set in his ways, Luke is always willing to adapt for the people he cares about. Because underneath that gruff exterior is a total sci-fi nerd who loves it when Lorelai pushes him out of his comfort zone. Plus, he's the one who has the coffee.

item.description: Not all men in Stars Hollow are created equal

item.title: 25 Gilmore Girls Trivia Questions Only Superfans Will Know

media:content.media:description: It's been 20 years since Gilmore Girls debuted on The WB, introducing the world to Stars Hollow and the fast-talking mother-daughter duo, Lorelai and Rory Gilmore (Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel). If you're anything like us, you've rewatched the series several times in the years since, and feel as though you know the Gilmores, Luke (Scott Patterson), Sookie (Melissa McCarthy), Lane (Keiko Agena), Paris (Liza Weil), Kirk (Sean Gunn), and the rest of the Stars Hollow bunch as well as your own family. So we decided to put this knowledge to the test with this ultimate Gilmore Girls trivia quiz. These 25 questions aren't for the casual viewer and are designed to separate the Lorelais from the Parises. (Although, let's be honest: being a Lorelai is pretty great, so this really is a win-win scenario because who needs to ace tests when you run a quaint inn and are the queen of movie nights?)But if you want to see if you're a true superfan, click ahead to see how well you know Gilmore Girls with this ultimate trivia quiz!

media:content.media:title: 1. Who speaks the first line of the series?
Lorelai
media:content.media:description: "Please, Luke. Please, please, please!"

media:content.media:title: Christiane Amanpour
media:content.media:description: In the final episode, she gets to meet the CNN journalist in person.

media:content.media:title: 3. How old was actress Keiko Agena when she began playing Lane Kim?

media:content.media:description: Lane Kim is 15 years old in Season 1.

media:content.media:title: 4. Which major character was originally scripted as a woman?
Luke
media:content.media:description: The producers rewrote the role because they thought the show needed more testosterone.

media:content.media:title: 5. Which of the Gilmore Girls actresses hates coffee in real life?
Alexis Bledel
media:content.media:description: She drank Coke instead.

media:content.media:title: 6. Which musician sings the Gilmore Girls theme song?
Carole King
media:content.media:description: She also guest stars in Season 3.

media:content.media:title: 7. Which Glee star appears as a nurse in Season 1?
Jane Lynch
media:content.media:description: She wore a pink cardigan.

media:content.media:title: 8. What is the name of Babette's cat that dies in Season 1?
Cinnamon
media:content.media:description: Lorelai and Rory help plan the wake.

media:content.media:title: 9. What is the population of Stars Hollow?

media:content.media:description: A town sign in Season 1, Episode 2 reveals this information.

media:content.media:title: 10. Which actress had a part written specifically for her?
Liza Weil
media:content.media:description: The part of Paris Geller was written for Weil after she tested for the role of Rory.

media:content.media:title: 11. Which actress also appeared in Dirty Dancing?
Kelly Bishop
media:content.media:description: She played Marjorie Houseman.

media:content.media:title: 12. What does Rory shoplift after her first kiss with Dean?
Cornstarch
media:content.media:description: It was an accident!

media:content.media:title: 13. Which character is referenced but never appears on the show?
Lane Kim's father
media:content.media:description: He lives with Lane and her mother.

media:content.media:title: 14. Which real-life band is Hep Alien's guitarist, Gil, a member of?
Skid Row
media:content.media:description: Their song "18 and Life" plays during one of the episodes.

media:content.media:title: 15. Which actress was originally tapped to play Sookie, but has a different role in Season 1?
Alex Borstein
media:content.media:description: She guest stars as the harp player, Drella, instead.

media:content.media:title: 16. Who was Richard engaged to before Emily?
Pennilyn Lott
media:content.media:description: Emily was the "other woman" until Richard eventually broke it off with Pennilyn. Scandalous!

media:content.media:title: 17. Who has the last line in the series' original run?
Rory
media:content.media:description: "I guess so."

media:content.media:title: 18. To earn extra credit, Chilton students sang the school song in what language?
Latin
media:content.media:description: Overachievers.

media:content.media:title: ​19. What is the name of the secret society of women that Rory joins?
The Puffs
media:content.media:description: Sandra Day O'Connor is said to be a member.

media:content.media:title: 20. What was Luke's nickname in high school?
Butch
media:content.media:description: He's not proud of it.

media:content.media:title: 21. Which classic film has a character named Lorelei Lee?
Gentlemen Prefer Blondes
media:content.media:description: Rory's middle name is spelled "Leigh."

media:content.media:title: 22. Which real-life town is Stars Hollow based on?
Washington Depot, Conn.
media:content.media:description: Gilmore Girls writer Amy Sherman-Palladino stayed there once when she took a trip to see Mark Twain's wallpaper at the Mark Twain House & Museum in Hartford, Conn.

media:content.media:title: 23. Which day of the year is Luke's "dark day"?
November 30
media:content.media:description: It's the day his father passed away.

media:content.media:title: 24. What item does Lorelai constantly have to borrow?
A pen
media:content.media:description: It becomes a running joke.

media:content.media:title: ​25. What was the last team that actor Scott Patterson played for during his professional baseball career?
Columbus Clippers
media:content.media:description: He wears the team's hat in Season 7.

item.description: Think you know the world of Rory and Lorelai Gilmore? Take our quiz and test your IQ on the fast-speaking ladies of Stars Hollow
item.category: Gilmore Girls: A Year In The Life
item.dc:creator: Glenn Gaslin

item.title: The Bachelorette: Meet Clare Crawley's Suitors

media:content.media:title: The Bachelorette Season 16 Cast
media:content.media:description: The premiere of The Bachelorette Season 16 is around the corner and Clare Crawley will have her chance to find love when 31 strapping men compete for her heart. ABC has finally released the names, ages, occupations, and photos for the lucky bachelors so you can start making your picks for first impression roses, front runners, and villains early. Of course, this season will work a little differently with Tayshia Adams reportedly taking over the titular role of the show shortly into the season. So you'll have to look out for who might make a good fit for her as well! There are plenty of Blakes, Zac/Zachs, and Tylers from you to choose from, so let's meet these guys already.
